URL-rewriting

Enhance developer productivity, usability, and security

  • Lincoln Baxter, III
  • Senior Software Engineer, Red Hat
  • 06.09.13
  • Welcome!

@lincolnthree

  • Founder of OCPsoft

What is URL-rewriting?

Any manipulation of the HTTP Request/Response lifecycle.

"Judgements prevent us from seeing the good that lies beyond appearances."

-- Wayne Dyer

We've got problems:

  1. Missing or relocated resources
  2. Readability & clutter
  3. Formatting of useful information
  4. Revealing sensitive information
  5. Validation of user input
And many more.
"URL-rewriting - not a good choice for doing it wrong."

1. Missing or relocated resources

404

Slide not found.

Wtf?

robo.to

github.com

tosh.com

blippy.com

"What does it mean?"
It's a distraction from failure.

There are two ways to have a magical 404 experience.

  1. The page existed and now does not ( the website sucks )
  2. The page never existed ( you suck )
Neither is going to make anyone happy.

What do we do about it? (easy)

  • 301 MOVED PERMANENTLY
  • 302 MOVED TEMPORARILY
180 Days.

Several options

Apache mod_rewrite
Tuckey URLRewriteFilter
OCPsoft Rewrite

3. Formatting useful information

http://example.com?c=shoes&app=store&pid=1&buy=true

Be cool.

http://example.com?c=shoes&app=store&pid=1&buy=true

http://example.com / store / shoes / 1 ? buy=true

What are you most afraid of when you buy a used car?

You never know what you are going to get.

Do you trust me?

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oHg5SJYRHA0

Build trust by reducing clutter. Use clean, transparent URLs.

http://www.youtube.com/watch/rick-rolld-again

4. Revealing sensitive information

microsoft.com FAQ

*Blush*

  • .jsf
  • .do
  • .php
  • .seam
  • .rb
  • .cgi
  • .faces
  • .asp
  • .jsp
  • .*

/

A good magician never reveals their implementation.

"Served by: Apache HTTPd 2.0.15 (build #3312 - 08/12/2011)"
Clean unnecessary information from headers and error pages!

5. Validation of user input

If you have to expose data, remember that URLs and headers are USER INPUT and are VULNERABLE.

Aspect Security says:

Two of three recent security vulnerabilities in web-frameworks are URL-based .*

* Aspect-Security-The-Unfortunate-Reality-of-Insecure-Libraries

You can secure existing applications

.addRule()
    .when(Direction.isInbound()
       .and(URL.matches("{badthings}")
           .or(Header.exists("{badthings}"))
           .or(Header.valueExists("{badthings}"))
       )
    )
    .perform(SendStatus.error(404)) // or take some protective action
    .where("badthings").constrainedBy(selectedCharacters)
Constraint<String> selectedCharacters = new Constraint<String>() {
      @Override
      public boolean isSatisfiedBy(Rewrite event, EvaluationContext context, String value)
      {
        return value.matches(".*[+%'\"^$#\\\\(\\\\)*<>].*");
        // Don't forget unicode!
      }
    }

Real life.

http://www.llbean.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/CategoryDisplay?categoryId=28&storeId=1&catalogId=1&langId=-1&nav=hp-gndp

http://llbean.com/kids

Another look.

http://www.llbean.com / webapp / wcs / servlet / CategoryDisplay ? categoryId=28 & storeId=1 & catalogId=1 & langId=-1 & &nav=hp-gndp

Clean and Validate!

HTTP/1.1: 418 - I'm a teapot; the resulting entity may be short and stout.

We've got problems:

  1. Missing or relocated resources
  2. Readability & clutter
  3. Formatting of useful information
  4. Revealing sensitive information
  5. Validation of user input

URL-rewriting!

Two types of rewriting tools.

  1. Proxy-based - Apache (inbound only)
  2. Filter-based - Java (inbound and outbound)

Basic things we can do with all types of URL-rewriting.

Redirection and relocation:

Inbound parameterization

Simple URL validation

Header validation and modification

"I have no personal investment in any of these tools."

-- blatant lie

Cool things we can do with Filter-based Java URL-rewriting

Transformation and canonicalization

.addRule()
    .when(Path.matches("/{path}.css"))
    .perform(Forward.to("/styles/{path}.less")
             .and(Transform.with(Less.class)))
.addRule()
    .when(Path.matches("/foo/{bar}")
    .perform(Forward.to("/foo/{bar}"))
    .where("bar").transposedBy(ToLowercase.class))

Complex conversion and validation

.when(Path.matches("/store/product/{pid}")
    .where("pid")
    .matches("\\d+\\w{3}\\d+")
    .bindsTo(El.property("productBean.product")
    .convertedBy(ProductConverter.class)
    .validatedBy(ProductValidator.class)))

Request interception

public class AccountVerifyInterceptor extends HttpConfigurationProvider 
    {
    
    @Inject private Account account;
    @PersistenceContext private EntityManager em;
    
    @Override
    public Configuration getConfiguration(final ServletContext context) {
       ConfigurationBuilder config = ConfigurationBuilder.begin();
       account.setEntityManager(em);
       Profile current = account.getLoggedIn();
       if (current.isPersistent() && !current.isUsernameConfirmed()) {
          return config
             .addRule().when(DispatchType.isRequest()
                       .and(Direction.isInbound())
             .perform(Forward.to("/account/confirm"))
    
             .addRule(Join.path("/account/confirm")
                       .to("/pages/accountConfirm.xhtml"));
       }
       return config;
    }

Some things you should NOT do with Java URL-rewriting

If it needs to run when your app is not, then don't run it in your app.

Bonus round!

But client-side applications are the future; can't I just ignore the URL and use web-sockets?

Bookmarks in client browser apps

Clean up the URL (HTML5)

It should be simple

But then we see something like...

  • example.com /
  • example.com / lincoln
  • example.com / lincoln / project-one
  • example.com / lincoln / lincoln

All better

Or just hard-code it...

If you have that luxury.

Let's find out, because It's DEMO time.
